content:
Collin Dougherty is a senior undergraduate at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln studying mathematics and psychology. He is particularly interested in how data can be used in a wide variety of fields, including sports analytics, trading, and social research. He worked in the field of sports analytics with the University of Nebraska.
  Download my resume.
summary: Collin Dougherty is a senior undergraduate at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln studying mathematics and psychology. He is particularly interested in how data can be used in a wide variety of fields, including sports analytics, trading, and social research.
title: Collin Dougherty

content:
After a long wait, the Huskers and Scott Frost have their quarterback for the 2022 season. Casey Thompson, who has two years of eligibility remaining, announced his commitment to Nebraska on Twitter last Friday.
‚ÄúAlways got an ace up my sleeve for whatever was dealt.‚Äù üÉè Bet on yourself. Nebraska, let‚Äôs get it. #WhyNot #GBR pic.twitter.com/Ko0FHqhue2
— Casey Thompson (@LilThurm) January 7, 2022  The get is a big one for newly hired offensive coordinator Mark Whipple and 4 year head coach Scott Frost, who is coming off his third straight losing season and entering a win or go home season at Nebraska. Thompson, a Junior, comes in with significant starting experience from his time at Texas and will provide the Huskers with much needed maturity at the position.
On paper, Thompson was one of the best QB‚Äôs in the Big 12 in the 2021 season, completing 165/261 passes for 2113 yards and 24 touchdowns to 9 interceptions. Thompson comes to Nebraska with a near 64% completion rate and 30-9 TD/INT ratio. He finished the season with a QBR of 154.7, good for 26th in the nation.
He replaces Nebraska veteran Adrian Martinez, who recently announced a decision to transfer to Kansas State. Martinez, both loved and the object of fierce criticism at times, battled multiple shoulder injuries while at Nebraska. He often started seasons extremely well, only to re-injure his throwing shoulder mid-season. He frequently played through pain and adversity and was a great team leader but struggled in big moments.
During his time at Nebraska, Martinez completed a solid 63.5% of his passes but struggled with a 45-30 TD/INT ratio. Martinez finished his career with a mediocre QBR of 139.5.
Casey Thompson on PaperCasey Thompson did not initially find himself as the starter at Texas this season, coming in to replace Hudson Card against Arkansas. After that, Longhorns coach Steve Sarkisian named Thompson the starter for each of the following 7 games.
Thompson started the season very well going 70/97 (72.2%) in his first 4 games as starter, with 13 TD‚Äôs to 3 INT‚Äôs. In his 4th game as starter against Oklahoma, he suffered a thumb injury on his throwing hand that plagued him for the rest of the season. After the Oklahoma game, the ball came out of his hand noticeably different, and he went just 91/151 (60.2%) with 10 touchdowns to 6 interceptions over the course of the following 6 games. Thompson would only play part of several of those 6 games, sharing time with Card as he struggled at times down the stretch.
Thompson never really looked himself after the thumb injury, with the ball coming out of his hand with noticeably less zip and accuracy. Despite that, he managed to lead the Longhorns to near upsets of Oklahoma State and Baylor. Though Thompson‚Äôs Longhorns struggled on the season, posting a 5-7 record, the woes are hard to pin on the Oklahoma City native, who led the Texas offense to 41 points per game on the days when he took the most snaps at QB.
On his career, prior to the thumb injury, Thompson was 99/139 (71.2%) with 20 touchdowns to 3 interceptions, posting a jaw dropping QBR of 200.4 in that span. That QBR would have placed him 2nd in the country in 2021, and 1st in 2020. Granted, his numbers are on significantly fewer plays than that of a full time starter, but it provides the best case scenario of what Thompson might be if he finds himself healthy with a full time role in Lincoln this fall.
Another ability that Thompson brings to the Huskers is an adeptness at evading pressure. In situations where Thompson had less than 2.5 seconds to get rid of the ball, he led the Big 12 in QBR, passing touchdowns, first downs, and was third in passing yardage. Thompson is a passing QB first, but is athletic enough to do damage with his legs, which he often used to avoid seemingly endless pressure. Texas‚Äôs offensive line struggled enormously this season, something which Nebraska fans can relate to. The Huskers are hoping for significant improvement in 2022, with experienced transfers Kevin Williams and Hunter Anthony joining Dominic Raiola‚Äôs revamped unit. If and when the offensive line struggles early in the season, Thompson will not be fazed, which is crucial to a successful offense for OC Mark Whipple.
Scouting Thompson on Film   On film, one thing that stands out about Thompson is his ability to go through his progressions. Husker fans have grown accustomed to quarterbacks who lock in on a target from before the snap, and Thompson will be a nice change of pace in that regard, quickly diagnosing defenses and throwing to the open man.
When healthy, Thompson showed excellent touch on throws from the pocket, though his deep ball was inconsistent at times. For the fall season, Thompson will want to improve in this area.
Thompson also struggled with passing on the run or on bootlegs, something which Martinez often made look effortless. It will be important for him to throw in the pocket, and the better the offensive line is, the better he will be.
Lastly, Thompson struggled down the stretch and made several costly mistakes, none more costly than a pick-6 against Oklahoma State that likely cost the Longhorns the game. While Thompson was battling a thumb injury that made his throws significantly easier to defend, he will need to learn from mistakes made down the stretch mentally.
The Cornhuskers have found an intriguing prospect at QB, and Thompson looks fully set to start in 2022. He joins a QB room with returners Logan Smothers and Heinrich Haarberg, and the Huskers may look to add another QB from the transfer portal. Thompson has the attention of Husker nation going into the fall. Time will tell if he can get Frost‚Äôs alma mater over the hump.
summary: After a long wait, the Huskers and Scott Frost have their quarterback for the 2022 season. Casey Thompson, who has two years of eligibility remaining, announced his commitment to Nebraska on Twitter last Friday.
title: Scouting New Huskers QB Casey Thompson

content:
With conference championships in the books and the college football playoff set, we have little to entertain ourselves with except looking at the most impressive parts of the 2021 season. One of the most outstanding storylines to come from the season was Georgia‚Äôs defense.
Entering the SEC title game, Georgia found themselves ranked #1 in points per game allowed among all teams in the 21st century, allowing a meager 6.9 points per game. With stats as absurd as these, many have crowned Georgia the best defense of the 21st century. Yesterday‚Äôs 41-24 drubbing at the hands of Alabama has tarnished their stats some, but they still find themselves among the very best. Let‚Äôs use R and data from sportsreference.com to see how Georgia stacks up.
library(rvest)library(tidyverse)library(lubridate)yearurl <- list("/cfb/years/2000-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2001-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2002-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2003-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2004-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2005-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2006-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2007-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2008-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2009-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2010-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2011-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2012-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2013-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2014-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2015-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2016-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2017-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2018-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2019-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2020-team-defense.html", "/cfb/years/2021-team-defense.html")uri <- "https://www.sports-reference.com"logs <- tibble()for (i in yearurl){log_url <- iyear_url <- paste(uri, log_url, sep="") # creating the url to fetchpage <- read_html(year_url)table <- page %>%html_nodes(xpath = '//*[@id="defense"]') %>%html_table(header=FALSE)table <- table[[1]] %>% rename(Rk=X1, School=X2, G=X3, Pts=X4, pCmp=X5, pAtt=X6, pPct=X7, pYds=X8, pTD=X9, rAtt=X10, rYds=X11, rAvg=X12, rTD=X13, Plays=X14, Yds=X15, Avg=X16, Pass=X17, Rush=X18, Pen=X19, Tot=X20, No=X21, penYds=X22, Fumbles=X23, Ints=X24, TO=X25) %>% filter(pCmp != "Cmp") %>% filter(pCmp != "Passing") %>% mutate(Year = i) %>% mutate(Year = gsub("/cfb/years/", "", Year)) %>% mutate(Year = gsub("-team.*", "", Year)) %>% mutate_at(vars(-School), as.numeric)logs <- bind_rows(logs, table) # binding them all togetherSys.sleep(3) # Sys.sleep(3) pauses the loop for 3s so as not to overwhelm website's server }We begin by fetching stats from sportsreference.com, focusing specifically on 2000-2021.
# Let's consider the top 10 defenses by scoring head(arrange(logs,(Pts)), n = 10)## # A tibble: 10 x 26## Rk School G Pts pCmp pAtt pPct pYds pTD rAtt rYds rAvg## <dbl> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl>## 1 1 Alabama 13 8.2 12.6 25.7 49.1 112. 0.5 29.7 72.2 2.4## 2 1 USC 13 9 15.3 29.4 52.1 134. 0.5 32 87.4 2.7## 3 1 Miami (FL) 11 9.4 11.7 26.4 44.5 138. 0.5 42.5 133. 3.1## 4 1 Georgia 13 9.5 17.8 31.8 56.2 172. 0.6 31.4 82.2 2.6## 5 1 Texas Chri~ 11 9.6 13 29.4 44.3 161. 0.9 35.9 84.4 2.3## 6 2 Florida St~ 12 10.3 18.3 37.3 49.2 203. 0.6 32.3 73.9 2.3## 7 1 Nebraska 14 10.4 16.7 35 47.8 179. 0.5 33.2 93.1 2.8## 8 1 Alabama 12 10.7 14.6 29.3 49.7 161. 0.8 30.1 94.3 3.1## 9 1 Alabama 14 10.9 15.5 28.4 54.7 174. 0.6 31.4 76.4 2.4## 10 1 LSU 14 11 15.2 34.1 44.7 185 0.9 28.6 67 2.3## # ... with 14 more variables: rTD <dbl>, Plays <dbl>, Yds <dbl>, Avg <dbl>,## # Pass <dbl>, Rush <dbl>, Pen <dbl>, Tot <dbl>, No <dbl>, penYds <dbl>,## # Fumbles <dbl>, Ints <dbl>, TO <dbl>, Year <dbl>Since at the end of the day, all that matters is the number on the scoreboard, let‚Äôs consider points per game allowed first. Georgia ranks #4 in the stat that matters most. #4 in the 21st century isn‚Äôt too shabby.
But what if we want to consider more than just points per game? Let‚Äôs also evaluate them in terms of the number of yards allowed per play, which I would argue is even more important than points per game.
To illustrate why I believe this is the case, consider the difference between a defense facing 80 plays per game against explosive Big 12 offenses, and a Big Ten team which controls time of possession and is accustomed to facing only 50 plays per game. We would expect the Big 12 defense to give up more yards due to pace of play, but this does not necessarily make the Big 10 defense better.
Case in point: Iowa-Wisconsin, vs.¬†Oklahoma State-Oklahoma. Those games are going to play out completely differently simply based on pace of play.
# Let's consider the top 10 defenses by Yards Per Play ypp <- logs %>% select(School, Avg)head(arrange(ypp,(Avg)), n = 10)## # A tibble: 10 x 2## School Avg## <chr> <dbl>## 1 Alabama 3.3## 2 North Carolina State 3.5## 3 Virginia Tech 3.6## 4 Texas Christian 3.6## 5 Ohio State 3.6## 6 USC 3.6## 7 Kansas State 3.7## 8 Texas Christian 3.8## 9 Southern Mississippi 3.8## 10 Texas 3.8This is a good start, but things are starting to get confusing. A lot of these teams didn‚Äôt show up in our top 10 defenses by scoring. Georgia doesn‚Äôt show up at all.
To simplify, let‚Äôs make our own ranking of a ‚Äúgreat defense‚Äù. The components of a good defense are many, but on paper we can make it remarkably simple. How good is their pass defense, rush defense, and do they force turnovers? Most importantly, how many points a game are they giving up?
We can take these 4 categories and make a new, composite stat, which combines all 4. In order to do this, we will use a z-score. A z-score is a numeric value, where which compares how much better or worse you are than average teams, and standardizes it, making it perfect for comparison across stats with different scales. We will find the z-score for each of our 4 stats and sum them to get a new composite ranking.
logs <- logs %>% mutate(zScoreRushing = -(rAvg - mean(rAvg)/sd(rAvg))) %>% mutate(pAvg = pYds/pAtt) %>% mutate(zScorePassing = -(pAvg - mean(pAvg)/sd(pAvg))) %>% mutate(zScoreScoring = -(Pts - mean(Pts)/sd(Pts))) %>% mutate(zScoreTurnovers = (TO - mean(TO)/sd(TO))) %>% mutate(zScoreComposite = (zScorePassing + zScoreRushing + zScoreScoring + zScoreTurnovers))top10 <- logs %>% select(School, Year, Pts, pAvg, rAvg, TO, rYds, pYds, zScoreComposite)top10 <- top10 %>% filter(zScoreComposite > -3.52)stop10 <- top10 %>% select(School, zScoreComposite)head(arrange(stop10,desc(zScoreComposite)), n = 10)## # A tibble: 10 x 2## School zScoreComposite## <chr> <dbl>## 1 Alabama -0.0772## 2 Miami (FL) -0.274 ## 3 USC -0.710 ## 4 Texas Christian -1.50 ## 5 Florida State -1.98 ## 6 Nebraska -2.95 ## 7 Georgia -2.95 ## 8 LSU -2.96 ## 9 Texas Christian -3.23 ## 10 Kansas State -3.51We find Georgia sitting at a respectable 6th on our new ranking. For perspective, yesterday when I ran these numbers, Georgia came out on top. With the updated numbers, Georgia‚Äôs most proximal comparison is the Nebraska defense of 2009 which held Colt McCoy‚Äôs #3 Texas to 12 points in the Big 12 championship game, and the LSU defense of 2003.
georgia <- logs %>%filter(School == "Georgia" & Year == 2021) logs %>%ggplot() + geom_point(data = logs, aes(x=Yds,y=Pts), color = "grey") + geom_point(data = georgia, aes(x=Yds,y=Pts), color = "red") +geom_smooth(data = logs, method='lm', aes(x=Yds, y=Pts), formula= y~x) +geom_hline(yintercept=mean(logs$Pts, na.rm = TRUE), color="dark grey") + geom_vline(xintercept=mean(logs$Yds, na.rm = TRUE), color="dark grey") + geom_text(aes(x=250,y=8, label="Georgia"), color="red") +labs(x = "Yards per Game Allowed", y = "Points per Game Allowed", title = "Despite the Lackluster Performance Yesterday...", subtitle = "Georgia stacks up among the best in the 21st Century on Defense", caption = "By: Collin Dougherty | Data Source: sportsreference.com") + theme_minimal() +theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"))Even though they find themselves slipping a bit in the rankings, and will likely continue to do so as they face the best teams in the country in the playoffs, we can see with a quick visualization just how elite this defense has been this year. Only a few other defenses of the past 21 years find themselves in the same region of this chart as Georgia.
georgia <- logs %>%filter(School == "Georgia" & Year == 2021) logs %>%ggplot() + geom_point(data = logs, aes(x=Avg,y=Pts), color = "grey") + geom_point(data = georgia, aes(x=Avg,y=Pts), color = "red") +geom_smooth(data = logs, method='lm', aes(x=Avg, y=Pts), formula= y~x) +geom_hline(yintercept=mean(logs$Pts, na.rm = TRUE), color="dark grey") + geom_vline(xintercept=mean(logs$Avg, na.rm = TRUE), color="dark grey") + geom_text(aes(x=4,y=8, label="Georgia"), color="red") +labs(x = "Yards per Play Allowed", y = "Points per Game Allowed", title = "Is Georgia Outperforming their Stats?", subtitle = "Georgia gives up less points per game than their yardage predicts", caption = "By: Collin Dougherty | Data Source: sportsreference.com") + theme_minimal() +theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"))Just for fun, I decided to run a linear regression on Yards per Play allowed and Points per Game allowed. What resulted is this graph. Teams below the blue line have allowed fewer points than we would have expected based on the number of yards per play they give up. We see that Georgia has been one of those teams which has slightly outperformed what we would have expected based on the stats. But at the end of the day, Kirby Smart only cares about the points on the scoreboard.
defense21 <- logs %>% filter(Year == 2021 & Pts <17)yards <- defense21 %>% select(School, rYds, pYds)yards <- yards %>% pivot_longer(cols=contains("Yds"), names_to="Type", values_to="Yds")ggplot() + geom_bar(data=yards, aes(x=reorder(School, -Yds), weight=Yds, fill=Type)) + coord_flip() + labs(x = "Team", y = "Yards per Game Allowed", title = "2021's Best Defenses by Yardage per Game", subtitle = "Georgia stacks up among the best in 2021 on Defense", caption = "By: Collin Dougherty | Data Source: sportsreference.com") + theme_minimal() +theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"))Let‚Äôs compare Georgia to their 2021 peers, which are more fresh in our collective memories. We have passing yards per game allowed in red and rushing yards per game allowed in blue. Overall, Georgia comes in just behind Wisconsin for best defenses on a yards per game scale, and just ahead of Oklahoma State. The fact that Oklahoma State held teams to such low yardage seems especially impressive when considering the pace of play in the Big 12 compared to the Big 10 and SEC.
Interestingly, the #4 and #5 defenses find themselves in the playoffs with Georgia.
Alternatively, using the composite stat we made earlier, Georgia ranks #1 this year, Cincinnati ranks #2, Michigan comes in at #7 and Alabama trails the pack at #15.
Begin mentally preparing for a lot of punts in this playoff. Will Alabama‚Äôs offense carry the day? Or will the outstanding defenses of Michigan, Georgia, and Cincinnati prove insurmountable?
yearteam <- logs %>% mutate(yrtm = paste(School, Year, sep=", "))defenses <- yearteam %>% filter(Pts <12)pts <- defenses %>% select(yrtm, Pts)ggplot() + geom_bar(data=pts, aes(x=reorder(yrtm, -Pts), weight=Pts)) + coord_flip() + labs(x = "Team", y = "Points per Game Allowed", title = "The Best Defenses by Points per Game", subtitle = "Georgia stacks up among the best in the One Stat that Matters", caption = "By: Collin Dougherty | Data Source: sportsreference.com") + theme_minimal() +theme(plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"))No matter which way you slice it though, all that matters when the clock hits zero is the number of points on the board. In this regard, Georgia 2021 finds themselves among the best of the century. I hope we see more of the same in what looks like it could be the lowest scoring college football playoff yet.
summary: With conference championships in the books and the college football playoff set, we have little to entertain ourselves with except looking at the most impressive parts of the 2021 season.
title: We Thought Georgia Had the Best Defense of the 21st century. Until Yesterday.

content:
The 2021 season has been quintessential Nebraska football under Scott Frost. Frost has raised his total losses in one score games to 17 since becoming the coach at Nebraska, with a record of 5-17 in such contests. Husker fans continue to debate whether or not his team is making progress. Any progress that has been made is hidden underneath an ugly 3-5 record, placing the Huskers last in the Big Ten West. But under the surface, a much more optimistic picture does indeed appear.
Many Nebraska fans have begun to complain louder and louder, and Frost‚Äôs seat is growing warmer by the loss. While Athletic Director Trev Alberts has expressed support and indicated that he is pleased with the improvements that have been made, many fans are left asking, ‚Äúwhat improvements‚Äù? After all, the Huskers have a record of 3-5 as of today, and their best season was arguably Frost‚Äôs first.
Every season experiences fluke outcomes. Is it possible that Nebraska has just been really unlucky? Cursed, even? That‚Äôs the question we set out to answer today. Between calls of ‚Äújoint possession‚Äù and ‚Äúdefensive delay of game‚Äù, there is reason to expect the Huskers have been at least a little unlucky.
Using data from collegefootballdata.com, I was able to run a simple linear regression which was able to predict 83% of 2019 games accurately in a backwards-looking fashion. For example, given all the games of 2019 and the stats of each game, it was able to correctly predict the outcome of the game, based only on its statistics, 83% of the time. The model is based on 3 factors which were highly predictive and independent: Predicted Points Added, Success Rate, and Explosiveness. I have dubbed this ‚ÄòThe Triadic Model of College Football‚Äô. The three factors which make up the Triadic Model are briefly described here.
Predicted Points Added: ‚ÄúPPA uses Expected Points to measure the outcome of a play. It takes the EP value from the beginning of a play (e.g.¬†2nd and 5 at the 50) and subtracts it from the EP value resulting from the play (e.g.¬†rush for 10 yards results in 1st and 10 from the 40).‚Äù [Credit.]
Success Rate: The success rate of a play is well defined in college football analytics circles. A successful play counts as any of the following:- Gaining 50% of the yardage to go on 1st down- Gaining 70% of the yardage to go on 2nd down- Gaining 100% of the yardage to go on 3rd downThe success rate is thus the number of successful plays divided by the sum of all plays.
Explosiveness: ‚ÄúExplosiveness measures the average EPA on plays which were marked as successful. It uses this site‚Äôs EPA implementation (known as PPA).‚Äù [Credit.]
In sum, these three factors are all positively correlated with winning. More successful plays, explosiveness, and predicted points added all correlate to more points scored. The inverse applies for defenses. When running the Triadic Model, we can not only predict wins and losses, but even specific scores, with a high degree of accuracy. The Triadic Model is simple, it excludes garbage time (Garbage Time occurs when one of the following scenarios is met: Scoring margin is 38+ points in the 2nd quarter, 28+ points in the 3rd quarter, or 22+ points in the 4th quarter), and it doesn‚Äôt factor in turnovers or special teams, which are demonstrably key aspects of winning. But, sometimes simple models are just as good, and an 83% accuracy rating seems to point in this direction.
At some point in the future, I hope to incorporate turnover and special teams stats, which should help increase accuracy even more. It would also be worthwhile to consider garbage time stats, as a backwards-looking model is only interested in what actually happened. The model without garbage time stats should come in handy later on, when looking to predict how a team will do in future games. By way of example, the current model is known to underestimate scoring margins in blowouts because of the exclusion of garbage time stats.
Without further ado, let‚Äôs dive into what the Triadic Model has to say about the Huskers 2021 season.
html {font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, 'Segoe UI', Roboto, Oxygen, Ubuntu, Cantarell, 'Helvetica Neue', 'Fira Sans', 'Droid Sans', Arial, sans-serif;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_table {display: table;border-collapse: collapse;margin-left: auto;margin-right: auto;color: #FFFFFF;font-size: 16px;font-weight: normal;font-style: normal;background-color: #000000;width: auto;border-top-style: solid;border-top-width: 2px;border-top-color: #A8A8A8;border-right-style: none;border-right-width: 2px;border-right-color: #D3D3D3;border-bottom-style: solid;border-bottom-width: 2px;border-bottom-color: #A8A8A8;border-left-style: none;border-left-width: 2px;border-left-color: #D3D3D3;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_heading {background-color: #000000;text-align: center;border-bottom-color: #000000;border-left-style: none;border-left-width: 1px;border-left-color: #D3D3D3;border-right-style: none;border-right-width: 1px;border-right-color: #D3D3D3;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_title {color: #FFFFFF;font-size: 125%;font-weight: initial;padding-top: 4px;padding-bottom: 4px;border-bottom-color: #000000;border-bottom-width: 0;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_subtitle {color: #FFFFFF;font-size: 85%;font-weight: initial;padding-top: 0;padding-bottom: 6px;border-top-color: #000000;border-top-width: 0;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_bottom_border {border-bottom-style: solid;border-bottom-width: 2px;border-bottom-color: #D3D3D3;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_col_headings {border-top-style: solid;border-top-width: 2px;border-top-color: #D3D3D3;border-bottom-style: solid;border-bottom-width: 2px;border-bottom-color: #D3D3D3;border-left-style: none;border-left-width: 1px;border-left-color: #D3D3D3;border-right-style: none;border-right-width: 1px;border-right-color: #D3D3D3;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_col_heading {color: #FFFFFF;background-color: #000000;font-size: 100%;font-weight: normal;text-transform: inherit;border-left-style: none;border-left-width: 1px;border-left-color: #D3D3D3;border-right-style: none;border-right-width: 1px;border-right-color: #D3D3D3;vertical-align: bottom;padding-top: 5px;padding-bottom: 6px;padding-left: 5px;padding-right: 5px;overflow-x: hidden;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_column_spanner_outer {color: #FFFFFF;background-color: #000000;font-size: 100%;font-weight: normal;text-transform: inherit;padding-top: 0;padding-bottom: 0;padding-left: 4px;padding-right: 4px;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_column_spanner_outer:first-child {padding-left: 0;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_column_spanner_outer:last-child {padding-right: 0;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_column_spanner {border-bottom-style: solid;border-bottom-width: 2px;border-bottom-color: #D3D3D3;vertical-align: bottom;padding-top: 5px;padding-bottom: 5px;overflow-x: hidden;display: inline-block;width: 100%;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_group_heading {padding: 8px;color: #FFFFFF;background-color: #000000;font-size: 100%;font-weight: initial;text-transform: inherit;border-top-style: solid;border-top-width: 2px;border-top-color: #D3D3D3;border-bottom-style: solid;border-bottom-width: 2px;border-bottom-color: #D3D3D3;border-left-style: none;border-left-width: 1px;border-left-color: #D3D3D3;border-right-style: none;border-right-width: 1px;border-right-color: #D3D3D3;vertical-align: middle;}#pmmyppooaf .gt_empty_group_heading {padding: 0.5px;color: 65%;}Computer Modeling Says Nebraska Deserves to Be 6-2Are the Huskers cursed, or is the problem bigger than that?OpponentScorePredictedIllinois22 - 3035 - 23Michigan29 - 3230 - 29Michigan State20 - 2330 - 21Minnesota23 - 3026 - 30Buffalo28 - 339 - 18Oklahoma16 - 2328 - 42Northwestern56 - 760 - 28Fordham52 - 735 - 33By: Collin DoughertyPerhaps unsurprisingly, the model indicates Nebraska has indeed underperformed. What may come as a surprise to many, however, is the margin by which that underperformance has come. Our model predicts a 6-2 record for the Cornhuskers. Given the strength of schedule faced to date (TeamRankings currently says it ranks 13th in difficulty, FPI currently ranks it 5th), the Huskers have played remarkably well. With a 6-2 record, a top 15 rating would likely follow. And yet the Huskers receive no votes for the top 25, sitting instead at a lowly 3-5, last in the Big Ten West.
The model predicts a nail-biting win against Michigan, a blowout win over Illinois, and a comfortable win against Michigan State on the road. It also feels confident the Huskers laid an egg against Minnesota, with a predicted loss on the road, and suggests maybe the Huskers were lucky to keep Oklahoma within one score based on how they played.
Let‚Äôs visualize the Huskers season further. Instead of looking at total yardage gained and allowed, we will look at yards per play and yards per play allowed. These stats help take into account pace of play and provide a more accurate picture of how a team is playing.
Nebraska, perhaps unsurprisingly at this point, finds itself among the better teams in college football when looking at YPP. But zooming in, we may be surprised at just how good their company is.
The Huskers nearest comparisons in YPP? #1. Georgia(7-0), #4. Ohio State(6-1), #2. Cincinnati(7-0), #3 Alabama(7-0), #8. Michigan State(7-0), #16 Baylor(6-1), #22. Iowa State(5-2), and only one unranked team, Florida(4-3), yes, the same Florida that took Alabama to the wire.
Looking even deeper, we see that not only has Nebraska badly underperformed, it is in fact one of only 3 teams to do so at such a dramatic clip this season, joining the ranks of Florida State and Western Kentucky.

Collin DoughertyAnd for the Husker fans who have hope that this will revert over the course of the season, perhaps it is noteworthy that only one remaining opponent - Iowa - has overperformed. Yes, even Ohio State has underperformed at 6-1, with the model suggesting they deserved to win against Oregon. The Huskers will face stiff tests these next four games. More optimistically, the numbers suggest they should be able to hang with all of them.

65%;}Remaining Nebraska Opponents Have Mostly UnderperformedTwo of Nebraska's Four Remaining Opponents Are Better Than Their Records, With One Notable Exception.TeamPredicted WinsWinsIowa46Ohio State76Purdue54Wisconsin44By: Collin DoughertyWhile it would be tempting to chalk up this season‚Äôs record entirely to bad luck and assume that the football gods will be more merciful next season, it is worth considering that this trend holds over the entirety of Scott Frost‚Äôs tenure at Nebraska. While Frost has gone a mere 15-25, the stats suggest his teams played at more of a 23-17 clip.

{text-align: center;}#usmlbopzbe .gt_right {text-align: right;font-variant-numeric: tabular-nums;}#usmlbopzbe .gt_font_normal {font-weight: normal;}#usmlbopzbe .gt_font_bold {font-weight: bold;}#usmlbopzbe .gt_font_italic {font-style: italic;}#usmlbopzbe .gt_super {font-size: 65%;}#usmlbopzbe .gt_footnote_marks {font-style: italic;font-weight: normal;font-size: 65%;}Computer Modeling Says Nebraska Has Underperformed for Several Seasons2021 isn't a fluke, the Huskers can't seem to get it done.TeamPredicted RecordRecordNebraska 20188 - 44 - 8Nebraska 20196 - 65 - 7Nebraska 20203 - 53 - 5Nebraska 20216 - 23 - 5Nebraska 2018-202123 - 1715 - 25By: Collin DoughertyConsidering Nebraska‚Äôs 5-17 record in one score games under Frost, a reversion to winning 50% of those games, as is typical in football, or going 11-11, would place his record at 21-19.
The Husker pundits will continue debating what needs to be changed - culture, offensive line, special teams, etc. - and rightfully so. The Huskers have several glaring holes that can be greatly improved. But it seems they have everything they need to perform at a highly successful level in the here and now. I leave the question then to the reader: is Nebraska cursed? Or is this just who they are?
summary: The 2021 season has been quintessential Nebraska football under Scott Frost. Frost has raised his total losses in one score games to 17 since becoming the coach at Nebraska, with a record of 5-17 in such contests.
title: Nebraska: Cursed or Consistent?

content:
As Bitcoin breaks all time highs and prices above 60k begin to feel normal, many are asking if they should begin their Bitcoin journey. The answer is a resounding yes. There are many reasons to buy Bitcoin. I hope to lay out some of my favorite reasons at some point in the future.
For now, I am starting a new journey of my own, dabbling a bit into trading. I won‚Äôt be using a significant amount of capital, as I hope to learn on the fly. For most people, trading is unnecessary. Buying and holding will do. I am a hodler at heart myself. But in the interest of learning more about what drives short term price action and my desire to try my hand at day trading have led me to this point.
I plan to update this post regularly with my trades and a brief explanation of why I am predicting a given short term price action. I may also post some of my options trading. In the interests of privacy and also because I am primarily trading a small amount at first, I will scale everything to a hypothetical initial investment of $10,000 USD. As I go, I hope to learn new things and devise new methods that will help better predict price action.
Thanks for joining me. I hope my insights prove useful.
10/31/2021: The last week has been mostly uneventful as Bitcoin price has moved mostly sideways within a tight range and altcoins have gone crazy. Shiba Inu, Doge, and others have pumped to absurd new heights before getting recked just as quickly. Let‚Äôs dive into some Bitcoin analysis.
We have two main patterns emerging: one bullish and one bearish with clear price target invalidations of each. This sets us up for a prime trading opportunity. We‚Äôll dive first into the bull flag that is developing.
We have a textbook example of a bull flag forming. For those who are unfamiliar, a bull flag is typically spotted amidst strong upward price action, followed by a period of consolidation. This shows conviction of buyers as the price drops, but is unable to fall significantly below the new prices. Eventually, the price breaks out of its upper resistance levels and goes on to make new highs. Bitcoin shows classic signs of having just broken out of its previous resistance, coming back to test the top of its previous resistance around 60k, where it promptly bounced back to higher levels. The next resistance is around 62.8-64k. After that is clear skies and price discovery. But there is another angle to consider to have a full picture of the current market.
Looking at the chart above, we see some hints of a head and shoulders pattern, typically signaling a bearish reversal. A head and shoulders pattern is indicated by a local peak, followed by a decline in prices before a new high. After this, there is a period of price decline before bulls make one last push, but they ultimately are stopped short of new highs, indicating a bearish reversal in market sentiment. We would be amiss to not acknowledge these potential signs of a reversal. As can be seen from the chart, 58k-60k remains an area of support, but losing this would indicate validation of the head and shoulders pattern.
How I‚Äôm playing this for now: a break below 58k would be a clear indicator to sell. I remain convinced we are in the midst of a bull market, and support would likely be found at the 52k level. I would look to re-enter the market there.
A break above 64k, however, would be a clear validation of the bullish flag signal, and a sign to hold, or re-enter the market if you‚Äôve been sidelined by recent moves. A break of 64k and I‚Äôm targeting the 85k region by mid-November, before the next consolidation.
My guess, given the current market dynamics, is that we see a bullish continuation in the coming days. But it‚Äôs good to always have an exit strategy prepared.
10/25/2021: I began the process of trading today, sending my initial investment to Kraken. Again, I will be tracking a hypothetical investment of $10,000, based on the returns on my trades. So from this point forward, I will refer to my account balance with respect to the hypothetical $10,000 initial capital, as is standard.
We had some interesting price action this morning. While my funds were not transferred in time to sell, we saw a spike in MACD and overbought levels on the RSI. I‚Äôll bide my time in the meantime. Short term price action looks generally positive. We had a strong retest of the EMA (the exponential moving average, seen as the blue line below), and have since bounced well short term.
I will be watching for the next sell signal, though I will not be surprised if we see continued positive price momentum over the near term, and I remain highly bullish on the current state of the market, fully expecting all time highs in the near future.
Current Account: $10,000 (+0.00%)
*I am not a financial advisor and the above does not constitute financial advice. Do your own research before making a purchase.
summary: As Bitcoin breaks all time highs and prices above 60k begin to feel normal, many are asking if they should begin their Bitcoin journey. The answer is a resounding yes.
title: Tracking My Bitcoin Trading Journey
